questions.text: A surgeon wants your advice about rust found on surgical instruments that are required for an operational procedure this afternoon. He has no other sets available. What is the most appropriate advice?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • When rusty instruments are found, the items need to be taken out of service so as not to compromise patient care. Loan equipment or alternative instruments need to be provided as a replacement.
  • Surgical instruments are made from high-grade stainless steel and are coated for protection against the aggressive nature of the decontamination process (passivation layer), which prevents the steel from rusting.
  • If at any time rust is found on the surface of an instrument, it indicates that either the passivation layer is compromised or there is weakness in the metal from which the instrument is made.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with rapidly progressive dementia undergoes a brain biopsy, which confirms sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (sCJD). The hospital's infection control team is tasked with decontaminating the neurosurgical instruments used in the procedure to prevent iatrogenic transmission of prions. Which of the following methods is MOST effective for prion decontamination?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Prions are the most resistant structure to sterilization and disinfection, and are best removed by Sodium hydroxide for 1 hr followed by autoclave at 121°C for 60 min.
  • Prions can be sterilized by either Steam sterilization or using a combination of sodium hydroxide and autoclaving, using 1 of the 4 following options:
    • Autoclave at 134°C for 18 minutes in a pre-vacuum sterilizer.
    • Autoclave at 132°C for 1 hour in a gravity displacement sterilizer.
    • Immerse in 1 N NaOH (1 N NaOH is a solution of 40 g NaOH in 1 L water) for 1 hour; remove and rinse in water, then transfer to an open pan and autoclave (121°C gravity displacement sterilizer or 134°C porous pre-vacuum sterilizer) for 1 hour.
    • Immerse in 1 N NaOH for 1 hour and heat in a gravity displacement sterilizer.

Incorrect options:

Autoclaving at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 lbs pressure (Option A) is effective for destroying heat-resistant microorganisms like bacterial spores, but not effective against prions.

5% formalin followed by autoclave at 121°C for 30 min (Option B) is not effective for the complete inactivation of prions.

Sodium hypochlorite for 10 min, followed by autoclaving at 121°C for 30 min (Option D), is not effective against the complete inactivation of prions.

questions.text: The equipment shown in the image is best sterilised by:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The equipment shown in the image is a 'Heart-Lung Machine', which is best sterilised by Ethylene Oxide.

Used for heat-sensitive plastics, electronics, and complex devices that cannot withstand steam sterilization. eg, Heart-lung machine, Implantable devices, Catheters, Endoscopic instruments, Pre-filled syringes.

Used in:

  • Heat-labile surgical instruments

The control used is Bacillus Globigii.

questions.text:
Assertion: The Rideal-Walker test is superior to the Chick-Martin test for evaluating the effectiveness of disinfection.
Reason: The Rideal-Walker test is specifically designed to compare disinfection efficacy in the presence of organic matter
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The Chick-Martin test is superior to the Rideal-Walker test for evaluating the effectiveness of disinfection.
  • The Chick-Martin test is specifically designed to compare disinfection efficacy in the presence of organic matter.

Phenol coefficient (Rideal-Walker) test:

  • It is determined by the dilution of the test disinfectant to sterilize the suspension of Salmonella Typhi in a given time divided by the dilution of phenol (standard disinfectant) to sterilize the suspension in the same time.
  • Phenol coefficient of > 1 is taken as satisfactory.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Only the phenolic disinfectants can be assessed
    • It does not evaluate the disinfectant ability to act in presence of organic matter.

Chick-Martin test (Modified Rideal and Walker test):

  • Here, the disinfectants are tested in the presence of organic matter (e.g., dried yeast, feces, etc.) to simulate the natural conditions.

Capacity (Kelsey-Sykes) test:

  • It assesses the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when repeatedly used microbiologically.

Kelsey and Maurer test: It determines whether the test disinfectant is effective in actual use in hospital practice.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24965238/

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method for sera/SERUM sterilization?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Filtration is the best method of sterilization of heat-labile liquids such as sera and solutions of sugars or antibiotics, toxins, and vaccines, as well as for the purification of air in laminar air flow systems.

Types of filtrations:

  • Membrane filtration: Membrane filters made of cellulose esters or other polymers have largely replaced other types of filters. They are routinely used in water purification and analysis, sterilisation and sterility testing, and for the preparation of solutions for parenteral use. They come in a wide range of average pore diameters. The pore size of microfiltration ranges from 0.1 - 5μm. 22 μm filters are the most widely used for filtering out bacteria.
  • Ultrafiltration (UF): UF membranes have a pore size range of 0.01 - 0.1μm. UF membranes reject particles such as silica, viruses, endotoxins, and proteins.
  • Nanofiltration (NF): NF membranes have a pore size range of 0.001 - 0.01μm. NF membranes can filter salts, sugars, and dyes.
  • High-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filter: This is a type of air filter used to remove at least 99.97% of airborne particles measuring up to 0.3μm in diameter. Larger particles are filtered with high efficiency. These filters are used in biosafety cabinets, operating theatres, laboratories, etc., to restrict the entry of infectious particles into the air.
  • Ultra-low penetration air (ULPA) filter can (theoretically) remove from the air at least 99.99% of dust, pollen, mould, bacteria, and any airborne particles with a size of 120 nanometres or more. These are used in the precision industry.

Incorrect options:

Autoclave (option B):

  • It is used at a temp of 121 degree celsius for 15 minutes for 15 psi pressure.
  • Used for:
    • Aprons
    • Instruments
    • sutures except catgut sutures
    • culture media except Lowenstein-Jensen) and LSS.
  • Control used is bacillus stearo-thermophilus
  • All sutures are sterilised by autoclave but catgut is sterilised by ionising radiation

Radiation (Option C):

  • Ionizing radiation:

  • Control used is Bacillus Pumilus

questions.text: A 25-year-old female is scheduled for an appendectomy. The patient is prepped for surgery in the surgical waiting area. As the posted intern secures a green cannula, an unexpected movement causes a needle stick injury, resulting in the spillage of blood on the floor. What is the recommended protocol for sterilizing a blood spillage on the floor?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

In case of Blood spillage in a clinical setting, the recommended Sterilant is Sodium hypochlorite.

Mechanism of action: Forms an Oxidising agent.

1% sodium hypochlorite is diluted and used depending on how much blood is spilled.

  • <10ml spill - 1:100 dilution
  • >10ml spill - 1:10 dilution

Blood Spill Management:

  • Block off the area to be disinfected.
  • Use a caution board.
  • Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves.
  • Have PPE ready
  • Use tongs or a pan and brush to sweep up as much of the broken glass (or container) as possible. Do not pick up pieces with your hands.
  • Discard the broken glass in a sharp container.
  • Use disposable towels to absorb as much of the body fluids as possible.
  • Saturate the area again with sodium hypochlorite (1:10 dilution) for a minimum of 20 mins
  • Rinse off the tongs, brush, and pan under running water and place them to dry
  • Remove gloves and discard them.
  • Wash your hands carefully with soap and water, and dry thoroughly with single-use towels
  • Record the incident in the incident book if a specimen was lost, or if persons were exposed to blood and body fluids.

Incorrect options:

Phenol (Option A): Used as disinfectant on hospital floors and walls.

Isopropyl alcohol (Option B): It has 70-80% alcohol, used for sterilizing instruments like a stethoscope and thermometer.

Povidone iodine (Option C): Used for treatment and prevention of infection in wounds.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sterilization: It is the process of destroying all living microorganisms, including viable spores, with a reduction of at least 106 log colony-forming units (CFU) of microorganisms and spores.
  • Disinfection: It is the process to destroy or remove most, if not all, pathogenic organisms, but not bacterial spores, with a reduction of at least 103 log CFU of microorganism but not spores.
  • Asepsis: It refers to the complete absence of viable pathogenic microorganisms in any environment.

questions.text: Composition of 'Savlon' is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Savlon contains:- Cetrimide (Cetavlon) + Chlorhexidine (Hibitane)

  • Chlorhexidine Gluconate (CHG):
    • Broad-spectrum antibacterial (Gram +ve & Gram -ve).
    • Persistent action (binds to skin, providing long-lasting protection).
  • Cetrimide:
    • Surfactant & disinfectant - enhances activity against Pseudomonas and fungi.
    • Helps in cleaning wounds by loosening debris.

Common Uses:

  • First aid for cuts, burns, and grazes (Savlon Antiseptic Cream).
  • Pre-surgical skin disinfection (Savlon Surgical Scrub – 4% CHG).
  • Hand sanitization (Savlon Hand Wash).
  • Mouthwash (Savlon Mouthwash for oral infections).

Savlon is the gold standard for pre-op skin prep (superior to iodine in clean-contaminated surgeries).

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12683517/

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with a complaint of cough, poor appetite, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature and breathlessness. The attending physician advised sputum examination for lab investigation. Sputum can be disinfected by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Sputum cannot be disinfected by chlorhexidine

Chlorhexidine mouth rinse before sputum collection may not reduce the contamination rate of mycobacterial cultures due to the presence of spore-forming bacteria.

Chlorhexidine:

  • Not Commonly Used for Sputum: Chlorhexidine is not commonly used for disinfecting sputum.
  • It is typically used as a skin antiseptic or for hand hygiene.
  • Chlorhexidine is not a mycobactericidal agent and is not the standard method for sputum disinfection.

Incorrect option:

Autoclave (Option A):

  • Autoclaves use high pressure and steam to kill microorganisms and spores, which is how they disinfect sputum samples.
  • It is used at temp of 121 degrees Celsius for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure.

Boiling (Option B):

  • Effective Method: Boiling is an effective method for disinfecting sputum.
  • Boiling inactivates or kills pathogens in sputum samples by damaging their structural components and disrupting their life processes.

Cresol (Option C):

  • Suitable Disinfectant: Cresol (or phenol) at a concentration of 5% is a suitable disinfectant for sputum.
  • It helps in killing or inactivating various pathogens present in sputum.
  • Cresol is a recognized disinfectant in healthcare settings and laboratories.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Spaulding classification?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Semi-critical devices need a high level of disinfectant

The Spaulding classification system categorizes medical and dental devices into three groups based on their potential risk of transmitting infections:

A) Critical items: These items come into direct contact with sterile tissues or the bloodstream, and they must be sterilized to prevent infection transmission. Examples include surgical instruments.

B) Semi-critical items: These items come into contact with mucous membranes or non-intact skin. They do not need to be sterilized but require high-level disinfection to ensure that they are safe for use. Examples include endoscopes and dental instruments.

C) Non-critical items: These items come into contact with intact skin and do not require sterilization or high-level disinfection. Low-level disinfection is typically sufficient. Examples include stethoscopes and blood pressure cuffs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female was admitted for pneumonia. The patient is hospitalized in a shared room. Due to her respiratory condition, she is on supplemental oxygen and is frequently monitored for any signs of infection. During her stay, a healthcare worker notices that the patient has coughed without covering their mouth. Concern arises regarding potential airborne pathogens and surface contamination in the room. What type of disinfection should be done for this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Sputum/droplets discharged from the patient are harmful to other people. Concurrent disinfection should be done for the above case because there is a high risk of spreading infection to others.

Concurrent disinfection: Application of disinfection methods after the discharge of infectious material from the body of an actively infected person/soiling.

  • Patient is still infectious (active pneumonia + uncovered cough → airborne droplets).
  • Shared room → Risk to other patients (e.g., Mycoplasma, Legionella, or *COVID-19* if not ruled out).
  • Actions needed:
    • Immediate surface disinfection (e.g., bed rails, oxygen mask).
    • Airborne precautions (N95 masks, HEPA filters if available).
    • Hand hygiene enforcement for staff/visitors.

Incorrect options:

Precurrent disinfection (Option A): It is done as a preventive measure to prevent the spread of infection.

Examples:- Pasteurisation of milk, Chlorination of water, and hand washing

Terminal disinfection (Option C): Application of disinfection measures after the patient has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation.

Terminal cleaning (Option D): Basic cleaning without germicidal agents (insufficient for pathogens).

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7751027/
